utterances: OK, we've just stepped inside the church, and it's a bare frame with a roof overhead but no insulation, no walls, just a skeleton of a building.
And in the middle of the dirt floor, there is an altar with a gold cross painted on it.
Alex, did you ever have services here?
We have.
For the first time, it was Christmas in 2010.
And did everyone just sneak in even though it was - even though...
Yes.
They surround us.
They force us to leave this place as soon as possible.
I see hanging on the walls there little wreaths with ribbons.
Is that left over from a Christmas celebration?
Yes.
This is the leftover from the Christmas celebration.
You could live somewhere that hardliners wouldn't come and try to burn down your church and say, kill them.
Why do you keep fighting to put your church here?
Because it's our right.
We have permission - legal.
I spoke with Muslims in Bogor to try to understand the opposition to the church.
People at the mosque told me the community is divided over it.
One man said it's a mistake to build a house of worship without local community support.
But no one I met expressed the kind of strong opposition that the Bogor Christian community encountered until I went back to Jakarta.
We reached by satellite phone a man who is in Daraa just this morning, he says filming the crackdown.
He's 35 years old and works in the mobile phone industry.
To protect himself he gave us a pseudonym, Iham.
Among the things he told us he saw are government snipers on rooftops and a population that's so afraid that few venture outside, even for Friday prayers.
(Through Translator) There's no power, no water, no bread, no gas, no fuel.
We are living on candlelight.
You're describing a city that's essentially under siege.
People are prisoners of their homes at this point?
(Through Translator) Yes.
Yes, it's a ghost town.
If anyone looks out of the window the snipers get them.
There are reports that protesters around Syria today and other cities around Syria today were chanting: With our blood, with our souls, we will sacrifice for you, Daraa.
Do you feel that you have the support of the country behind what started there in the south, in Daraa?
(Through Translator) Aside from the hypocrites, everyone is with us.
Only those that are benefiting from the current regime are with President Bashar Assad.
How hard is it to get in and out?
(Through Translator) You can only come and go from the city on the agricultural roads.
Can you describe the presence of the Syrian army in Daraa right now?
(Through Translator) The army's Fifth Division has joined with the people, unlike the Fourth Division.
And I have a list of martyrs, 47 names.
I have that with me now.
And we're not able to take the bodies to hospitals because thugs are stealing them.
We're placing them in large refrigerator trucks instead.
The number of wounded people is over 500.
Just to be clear, the people who have been killed, the names that you have on that list, when were they killed?
(Through Translator) These are people who were killed up until yesterday in the last three days.
There were children who were killed.
A child named Shiraz Imad ElBatak(ph) was killed and a woman who was eight months pregnant and her fetus were both killed.
And the martyr Jamaal Abdullah Abudabus(ph), an imam of the mosque, he was killed - he was assassinated at the mosque.
And Osema al-Masalim(ph), a nurse, was also killed.
You mentioned the Fifth Division of the army that you say has joined with the opposition, with the protesters.
Can you tell me more about that?
(Through Translator) Yes, the Fifth Division and the Fourth Division are exchanging bullets with each other.
The Fifth Division is protecting the people.
Massacres are happening, catastrophic massacres.
Is it something you were able to observe with your own eyes in Daraa?
(Through Translator) Yes.
Yes.
And I have a video but there's no Internet.
When communication is restored, I will upload this video and send it to human rights organizations, to Al-Jazeera and all news agencies.
And this firing that you're describing, was this today?
(Through Translator) Yes, today there is heavy fire.
And I would like to send a message through you to the United Nations and to human rights organizations.
And what is that message?
(Through Translator) I'm sending a plea to the United Nations and to all Arab leaders to support us.
I'm sending a plea to human rights organizations, President Obama, and all European countries to stand with the Syrian people against this fascist regime.
He is eradicating his people, complete eradication.
We have seen the international community respond militarily, of course, in Libya.
I'm wondering what you would want the international community to do in Syria, specifically.
(Through Translator) I don't want the international community to intervene militarily.
We will protect ourselves.
The international community should exert pressure on President Assad.
Iham, thank you very much for talking with us today.
Welcome (Foreign language spoken)
We've been hearing from a 35-year-old Syrian man.
Iham is a pseudonym we've used for his protection.
He was in the southern city of Daraa this morning and described the government crackdown there.
If the United States, or anyone else for that matter, decides to give weapons to the Libyan rebels, just whom exactly would they be arming?
Do the rebel fighters include potential terrorists?
Do some have al-Qaida ties?
Well, those questions were posed to NATO's military commander yesterday at a Senate hearing.
Here's what he had to say.
We have seen flickers in the intelligence of potential al-Qaida, Hezbollah.
We've seen different things.
But at this point, I don't have detail sufficient to say that there's a significant al- Qaida presence or any other terrorist presence in and among these folks.
That's Admiral James Stavridis yesterday.
Flickers in the intelligence, he said.
To talk a little bit more about what that might mean, we turn to Juan Zarate.
He's a former deputy national security adviser for combating terrorism under President Bush.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks, Melissa.
How strongly do you say those flickers are in talking about al-Qaida links among the Libyan rebels?
Well, I think that language that Admiral Stavridis used is a reflection of a lack of information.

I think what he and others in the intelligence community are trying to do is to try to piece together what we know about al-Qaida's presence historically in Libya, the radicalization problems we've seen historically, particularly in the northeast of Libya, near Benghazi, with data that we may have about who's fighting with the rebels at this point.
What about that historical presence that you mentioned?
What do we know about how active al-Qaida has been in Libya and whether Libyans became part of al-Qaida's core leadership?

And I think, finally, something to recall is that at the height of the foreign fighter problem that we had where suicide bombers played such a strategically devastating role in Iraq, a disproportionate number of those came from Libya.
It is interesting, if we think about this, that Moammar Gadhafi himself has been alleging that the Libyan uprising in the east was fanned by al-Qaida.
This is his claim.
(Singing) The Green Room is smoking, and the plaza burning down.
Throw my baby out of the window and let the joint burn down, all because it's carnival time.
Whoa, it's carnival time.
Oh, well, it's carnival time, and everybody's having fun.
The whole street is rocking from one side to the other.
The joints are jammed and packed and I'm about to (unintelligible), all because it's carnival time.
Whoa, it's carnival time.
Oh, well, it's carnival time and...
That's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Rebecca Roberts in Washington.
Neal Conan is on assignment.
Tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION, Neal Conan will be back with a special broadcast from Tucson, Arizona.
If you live and work in Southern Arizona, immigration isn't an abstract issue - it's part of your life.
Scenes from the border, that's tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And I also want to remind you about the survey we have going on our blog right now.
It's a series of questions dealing with what might be considered ethical gray areas.
It's at npr.org/blogofthenation and should take you only about five minutes to complete.
We'll post the results tomorrow afternoon.
